Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Intervention standards and prohibitions
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or pushing a
youth on any part of their body.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth was allegedly smacked in the face by Staff 1 in his
bedroom.
Investigation
I left a message for Complainant on 12/19/24 and 12/23/24. No
response to this date.
On 10/24/24, I spoke to Administrator 1. She reported there is no
video footage of this incident, nor any grievance or incident report
for the alleged incident.
I interviewed Staff 1 on 11/25/24 face to face at the facility. Staff 1
reported she completes “wake up” on Pod F. Staff 1 reported she
knocks on their bedroom doors and turns the lights on for them.
She provides them time to get up. If they do not wake up, then she
can open the door and go into the room to wake them up. Staff 1
reported she rarely has to go into the youth’s room to wake them
up. Staff 1 reported on this particular day, 10/18/24, Youth A
refused to get up. Staff 1 opened the door, went in, and stated it
was time to go to school. Youth A stated, “I don’t give a fuck.”
Youth A wrapped his t-shirt around his shoulder and head area
and Staff 1 reported she removed the t-shirt and took it. Staff 1
reported Youth A refused to get up and she left his room. Staff 1
reported she never hit Youth A or smacked Youth A across the
face.
On 12/19/24, Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility.
Youth A reported on 10/18/24, he refused to get up for school.
Youth A reported Staff 1 came into his room and took his sweater
off his face. Then she used the palm of her hand and smacked
2

him across the face. Youth A reported he didn’t say anything to
Staff 1 to provoke her to smack him. Youth A reported Staff 1 and
himself argue a lot and do not get along so maybe that is why she
smacked him. Youth A reported he has never seen her hit anyone
else.
On 12/19/24, I interviewed Youth B face to face at the facility.
Youth B reported Staff 1 works in the unit during the pods wake up
time. Youth B reported he has never seen Staff 1 hit Youth A.
Youth B reports during wake-up time, she turns the lights on and
knocks on the door. Youth B reported he has never heard Youth A
say he was hit by Staff 1 either.
I interviewed Youth C face to face at the facility on 12/19/24.
Youth C reported Staff 1 works the morning shift. Youth C
reported in the morning she tells everyone to get up and turns on
the light. Youth C reported he has never seen her hit any of the
youth.
I interviewed Manager at the facility on 12/19/24. Manager walks
around the facility and makes sure the facility is managed
properly. Manager reported she has never had any complaints
concerning Staff 1, nor heard that she has smacked any youth in
the facility. Manager reported Youth A does make up accusations
when he does not get his way.
Documents:
• I reviewed the agency Behavior Management Policy. It
does not allow smacking youth.
• I reviewed Staff 1’s personnel file. All clearances and
training are up to date.
• There are no incident reports or grievances for this
situation.
Analysis The agency is compliant with this rule. There is no evidence to
validate the allegations.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
3

Rule Code Intervention standards and prohibitions
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(iv) Verbal abuse including the use of derogatory or
discriminatory language including negative references to a youth's
background or appearance or mental state. Yelling, threats,
ridicule, or humiliation are strictly prohibited.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation It is alleged that staff call the youth at the facility derogatory
names.
Investigation I interviewed Staff 1 at the facility on 11/24/24. Staff 1 reported
she has never named called any youth in the facility and has
never heard any other staff name call the youth.
On 12/19/24, Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility.
Youth A reported Staff 1 has called the youth, “Bitches.” Youth A
reported other staff name call as well but was unable to provide
names.
On 12/19/24, I interviewed Youth B, face to face at the facility.
Youth B reported he has heard Staff 1 yell at Youth A and has
heard her call Youth A “Bitch” and a “Nigger” one time. Youth B
reported he has not heard any other staff name call the youth.
I interviewed Youth C face to face at the facility on 12/19/24.
Youth C reported he has never heard Staff 1 use profanity at the
youth.
I interviewed Manager at the facility on 12/19/24. Manager
reported she has never heard from anyone that Staff 1 uses
profanity with the youth.
I interviewed Staff 2 face to face at the facility on 12/19/24. Staff 2
reported she has only worked with Staff 1 a few times. Staff 2
reported Staff 1 is a newer staff and will sometimes be quick to
react and raise her tone with the youth but has never heard Staff 1
use profanity with the youth. Staff 2 reported she has not heard
other staff use profanity with the youth.
4

I interviewed Staff 3 face to face at the facility on 12/19/24. Staff 3
reported Staff 1 is nice, not timely, and she needs help with her
“temperament.” Staff 3 explained that Staff 1 has used profanity at
the kids and in conversation with the kids. Staff 3 reported when
the youth become escalated, she also becomes escalated and
starts to cuss and yell at them. Staff 3 reported she helped train
Staff 1 and did not see this temperament then but after her
training was completed. Staff 3 reported she had to redirect her a
couple of times for using profanity. Staff 3 reported she would
listen, but at times provide an attitude to her. Staff 3 reported she
has heard Staff 1 use the word “Nigger” towards the youth. Staff 3
reported she has heard her say, “Shut the fuck up.” Staff 3
reported she has heard Staff 1 use profanity in general, not
towards the youth but just in conversation. Staff 3 reported she
did not report this to anyone because everyone needs a job right
now.
Documents:
• Staff 1 has completed 66 hours of training and her “Shadow
Training Forms.
• I requested Staff 1’s supervision forms. Supervision forms
were not completed. Please see below additional finding.
• I reviewed the agency’s behavior management policy. The
policy does not allow verbal abuse.
Analysis The agency is in violation with this rule. Youth A, Youth B, and
Staff 3 all reported they have heard Staff 1 use derogatory names
towards the youth. Staff 3 worked with Staff 1 and reported she
did have to redirect her conversations. Staff 3 reported Staff 1’s
temperament was something Staff 1 needed to work on,
especially when the youth would escalate. Staff 2 reported Staff 1
would react quickly and raise her tone. This coincides with Staff
3’s interview as well.
Technical Assistance: Child safety is the responsibility of all staff
in the facility. Staff 3 reported she had been aware of Staff 1’s
language and name calling with the youth, but did not report this
to anyone. These are situations that, if known, the facility could
have provided a support to Staff 1 by providing additional
supervision or training. The agency is to ensure that all staff
understand professionalism and the mission of the facility. The
agency (as an example) may address this in policy under
professionalism or ethical behavior.
5

Consultation: The agency may want to address culture and
teamwork in team meetings or in supervision to ensure all staff are
aware of their responsibility to the youth they serve.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established

Rule Code Chief Administrator: responsibilities
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4116
Section (1) An agency shall assign the chief administrator responsibility
Description for the onsite day to day operation of the institution and for
ensuring compliance with these rules.
Violation Additional Findings
Type
Allegation The chief administrator did not ensure previous corrective action
plans (CAPS) were being implemented, resulting in non-
compliance.
Investigation Administrator 2 reported Administrator 1 has been terminated
from the chief administration position. It was discovered that there
were areas of her job responsibilities not being completed.
Administrator 2 reported they are working on a CAP binder to
ensure they complete CAPS. Administrator 2 reported when these
CAPS were written, the facility did not have the manpower to
achieve this type of supervision. Administrator 2 reported they
have hired case managers, and this now could be done.
Documents:
• I requested Staff 1’s supervision forms on 12/26/24 1/7/25,
1/9/25, and 1/16/25. The agency did not have these forms.
• I reviewed SIR CAP 2023C000854 and SIR CAP
2023C0000650. CAP 2023C0000650 documented the
agency would start 1 on 1 supervision with all staff (at all
levels) on a weekly basis. This would be implemented on
10/2/23. CAP 2023C0000854 documented the agency
would move from weekly supervision to bi-weekly
supervision for all staff. This would be implemented on
3/23/24.
6

Analysis The agency is non-compliant with this rule. The agency was not
implementing CAPS they had created.
Technical Assistance: Policies and job descriptions are to be
updated to reflect supervision changes outlined in the previous
CAPS. The agency is to assess what is feasible concerning
supervision of all personnel. More frequent supervision may occur
for newer staff and then less frequent as they grow into their
position. The previous CAPS signed by Administrator 1 are to be
reviewed by the facility and implementation ensured.
Consultation: it would benefit the agency to create a CAP binder
including all CAPS and placing all documentation mentioned in the
CAPS, in the binder. It would also benefit the agency to have
routine CAP meetings to discuss the current CAPs in place, the
compliance with those CAPS, and an assessment of the changes
in the facility the CAP may have produced. All parties responsible
for the implementation should be present to ensure all parties
know about the CAP.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
SIR 2025SIC0000217 dated 1/9/2025, CAP Approved 1/27/2025
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
